trans-unit.source: Custom Script extension on Windows | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Custom Script extension on Windows | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Automating Azure virtual machine configuration tasks using Custom script extension on Windows
trans-unit.target: Automating Azure virtual machine configuration tasks using Custom script extension on Windows

trans-unit.source: Custom Script Extension for Windows
trans-unit.target: Custom Script Extension for Windows

trans-unit.source: This article gives an overview of using Custom Script Extension on Windows using Azure PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: This article gives an overview of using Custom Script Extension on Windows using Azure PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: Virtual machine (VM) extensions are built by Microsoft and trusted third-party publishers to extend the functionality of the VM.
trans-unit.target: Virtual machine (VM) extensions are built by Microsoft and trusted third-party publishers to extend the functionality of the VM.

trans-unit.source: For an overview of VM extensions, see
trans-unit.target: For an overview of VM extensions, see

trans-unit.source: <html></html>Azure VM extensions and features<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: <html></html>Azure VM extensions and features<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: Custom Script Extension overview
trans-unit.target: Custom Script Extension overview

trans-unit.source: Custom Script Extension for Windows allows you to run PowerShell scripts on a remote VM, without logging into it.
trans-unit.target: Custom Script Extension for Windows allows you to run PowerShell scripts on a remote VM, without logging into it.

trans-unit.source: The scripts can be run after provisioning the VM or any time during the lifecycle of the VM without requiring to open any additional ports on the VM.
trans-unit.target: The scripts can be run after provisioning the VM or any time during the lifecycle of the VM without requiring to open any additional ports on the VM.

trans-unit.source: The most common use case for Custom Script Extension include running, installing, and configuring additional software on the VM after it's provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The most common use case for Custom Script Extension include running, installing, and configuring additional software on the VM after it's provisioned.

trans-unit.source: Prerequistes for running Custom Script Extension
trans-unit.target: Prerequistes for running Custom Script Extension

trans-unit.source: Install Azure PowerShell cmdlets version 0.8.0 or later from <html></html>here<html></html>.
trans-unit.target: Install Azure PowerShell cmdlets version 0.8.0 or later from <html></html>here<html></html>.

trans-unit.source: If the scripts are run on an existing VM, make sure VM Agent is enabled on the VM, if not follow this <html></html>article<html></html> to install one.
trans-unit.target: If the scripts are run on an existing VM, make sure VM Agent is enabled on the VM, if not follow this <html></html>article<html></html> to install one.

trans-unit.source: Upload the scripts that you want to run on the VM to Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Upload the scripts that you want to run on the VM to Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: The scripts can come from a single container or multiple storage containers.
trans-unit.target: The scripts can come from a single container or multiple storage containers.

trans-unit.source: The script should be authored in such a way that the entry script, which is started by the extension, starts other scripts.
trans-unit.target: The script should be authored in such a way that the entry script, which is started by the extension, starts other scripts.

trans-unit.source: Custom Script Extension scenarios
trans-unit.target: Custom Script Extension scenarios

trans-unit.source: Upload files to the default container
trans-unit.target: Upload files to the default container

trans-unit.source: If you have your scripts in the storage container of the default account of your subscription, then the following example shows how you can run them on the VM.
trans-unit.target: If you have your scripts in the storage container of the default account of your subscription, then the following example shows how you can run them on the VM.

trans-unit.source: The ContainerName is where you upload the scripts to.
trans-unit.target: The ContainerName is where you upload the scripts to.

trans-unit.source: The default storage account can be verified by using the Get-AzureSubscription –Default command.
trans-unit.target: The default storage account can be verified by using the Get-AzureSubscription –Default command.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a new VM, but the same scenario can be run on an existing VM as well.
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a new VM, but the same scenario can be run on an existing VM as well.

trans-unit.source: Upload files to a non-default storage container
trans-unit.target: Upload files to a non-default storage container

trans-unit.source: This scenario shows how to use a non-default storage either within the same subscription or in a different subscription for uploading scripts and files.
trans-unit.target: This scenario shows how to use a non-default storage either within the same subscription or in a different subscription for uploading scripts and files.

trans-unit.source: Here we’ll use an existing VM but the same operations can be done while creating a new VM.
trans-unit.target: Here we’ll use an existing VM but the same operations can be done while creating a new VM.

trans-unit.source: Upload scripts to multiple containers across different storage accounts
trans-unit.target: Upload scripts to multiple containers across different storage accounts

trans-unit.source: If the script files are stored across multiple containers, to run the scripts, you have to provide the full SAS URL for the files.
trans-unit.target: If the script files are stored across multiple containers, to run the scripts, you have to provide the full SAS URL for the files.

trans-unit.source: Add Custom Script Extension from the portal
trans-unit.target: Add Custom Script Extension from the portal

trans-unit.source: Browse to the VM in the <html></html>Azure preview portal <html></html> and add the extension by specifying the script file to run.
trans-unit.target: Browse to the VM in the <html></html>Azure preview portal <html></html> and add the extension by specifying the script file to run.

trans-unit.source: Uninstalling Custom Script Extension
trans-unit.target: Uninstalling Custom Script Extension

trans-unit.source: Custom Script Extension can be uninstalled from the VM using the following command.
trans-unit.target: Custom Script Extension can be uninstalled from the VM using the following command.

trans-unit.target: Using Custom Script Extension with Templates

trans-unit.target: To learn about using Custom Script Extension with Templates, see the documentation [here](virtual-machines-extensions-customscript -with template.md).
